Award.AwardTitle: Conference: 16th Annual Rustbelt RNA Meeting to be held October 17-18, 2014 at the Marriott City Center Downtown in Pittsburgh, PA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 16th annual Rustbelt RNA Meeting will be held October 17-18, 2014 at the Marriott City Center Downtown in Pittsburgh, PA. The meeting is an annual regional conference that promotes sharing of new research in RNA science, broadly defined. Recent years have witnessed breakthroughs in the identification and characterization of RNA switches and enzymes, as well as genome-wide approaches to RNA folding and regulation. A major goal of the meeting is to provide opportunities for trainee professional development through presentation of talks and posters; to meet that goal the majority of the talks and presentations will be given by students, postdoctoral associates and early-career faculty. These presentations are a key mechanism for trainees to interact with senior researchers and fellow students in their field. These interactions often form the foundation of long-lasting professional relationships and collaborations. Meetings such as this one fulfill a key mission of NSF by providing educational and development opportunities for the next generation of science professionals.

This year's meeting will draw regional participation from the Midwestern and Mid-Atlantic United States and provide students and PIs with the chance to learn and share RNA-related research. The meeting will cover topics ranging from long non-coding RNAs to tRNA modification to RNA structure-function studies. The meeting will feature a keynote lecture by Professor Manuel Ares Jr. (University of California, Santa Cruz), former president of the RNA Society and HHMI Professor. Unique features of the meeting will include 1) oral presentations in each session from research conducted by undergraduates, 2) featured poster area highlighting works from undergraduate researchers and PUIs, 3) travel awards for undergraduate and underrepresented minorities, and 4) a workshop on career transition for trainees hosted by group leaders from industry and academic research institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes  The Rustbelt RNA Meeting (RRM) is an annual regional meeting that focuses on RNA research. The RRM is held in the Midwest United States and attracts top-quality participants from research-intensive schools in the United States “Rustbelt.” A major goal of the RRM is to provide unique opportunities for trainee professional development through presentation of talks and posters. 

Overview  The 16th annual RRM meeting provided a professional scientific meeting at a very reasonable cost, which made it affordable for students and principal investigators from both major research institutions and primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) to attend. The 16th annual RRM was held in Pittsburgh, PA at the Marriott City Center on October 17-18, 2014. This was the first time the meeting was held in Pittsburgh, which offered several new advantages for the RRM. This location provided drivable access to longtime attendees from Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Kentucky, and New York State, and welcomed new attendees from West Virginia, Maryland, Kentucky, and eastern Pennsylvania.

The 2014 meeting assembled researchers with diverse backgrounds and interests in RNA, ranging from genomics to biophysics and so facilitated new learning experiences and collaborations for trainees and PI’s alike. With a full schedule of more than 162 posters and 36 oral presentations by student and post-doctoral trainees, the RRM provided a high-caliber interdisciplinary experience for participants. Notably, the meeting featured a keynote lecture by Professor Manuel Ares Jr. (University of California, Santa Cruz), former president of the RNA society and HHMI Professor, as well as a career roundtable featuring both Prof. Ares and Prof Marcel Bruchez from Carnegie Mellon, who provided an academic to industry transition perspective.

Intellectual Merit   The intellectual merit of the RRM is the sharing of new research in RNA science, broadly defined. Recent years have witnessed breakthroughs in the identification and characterization of RNA switches and enzymes, as well as genome-wide approaches to RNA folding and regulation. This RRM meeting drew together regional participation from the Midwestern and Midatlantic United States and provided students and PIs with the chance to learn and share RNA-related research. The meeting covered topics ranging from transcription to RNA chemistry to RNomics. Attendees were afforded the opportunity to learn new techniques and tools in the area of cellular, computational, and biophysical approaches. Both new trainees as well as senior scientists looking to start a new lab or move in new directions benefited from the talks, posters, and collaborative environment of the RRM. The RRM is a natural place for collaborations to arise for all different groups, including large research universities and PUIs.

Broader Impacts   The broader impacts of the RRM focused on providing an affordable and top quality interdisciplinary meeting in RNA science that undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral trainees can attend and participate in. The meeting has a rich history of featuring presentations by trainees. Approximately 2/3 of all attendees presented their research, either as a poster or a talk, and 34/36 talks were from students and post-doctoral scholars, as were the vast majority of the posters.  The poster session involved 162 posters and greater than 40 faculty members judged the posters. This helped to provide lively interaction at the posters, and interchange between trainees and PIs.
